Catalytic Chemistry Research Unit, School of Science, King Mongkut’s Institute of Technology Ladkrabang Chalongkrung Road, Ladkrabang Bangkok 10520 Thailand Acetylene in ethylene-rich feed can be removed via acetylene/ethylene cross-metathesis over WO3-supported catalysts at 450 °C, yielding 1,3-butadiene with cyclohexene as a minor product. The catalyst must be treated with ethylene at 600 °C to generate a genuinely active site of tungsten (IV) alkylidene species (W=CH2). The H2 treatment decreases surface WO concentration, and hence the activity. Raman spectroscopy shows that active single-site WO3 species, including mono oxo-WO3 ((O=)W(O-Si)3 and (O=)W(O-Si)4) and dioxo-WO3 species (O=)2W(O-Si)2) were generated in 2%WO3/SiO2, while the WO3 cluster and bulk WO3 exist in 3–5%WO3/SiO2 and 7%WO3/SiO2, respectively. The 5%WO3/NaX and 5%WO3/NaY provide lower activity due to coke formation over the acid sites. With high surface area and confined surface silanol of 5%WO3/MCM-41% and 5%WO3/SBA-15, in situ TR-EXAFS evidences the formation of only OW(O-Si)3. This species provides an isolated W=CH2 site with relatively higher activity and is less prone to coke formation than the WO3 cluster in 5%WO3/SiO2. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Cross-metathesis Acetylene removal Ethylene Tungsten oxide Silica Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Ethylene is an essential chemical building block widely used for polymerization in polymer synthesis. It is traditionally produced from the naphtha steam cracking process at high temperatures (∼700 °C), where hydrocarbon feedstock is thermally cracked to ethylene, propylene, and butene with a trace of polyunsaturated products, such as acetylene and butadiene [1–4]. However, high purity ethylene is particularly required for polymerization because polyunsaturated impurities readily poison the Ziegler–Natta catalyst, leading to a rapid deactivation [5–9]. Accordingly, selective hydrogenation of acetylene is typically applied for high purity ethylene treatment, exploiting expensive platinum and palladium catalysts. However, competitively excessive ethylene and acetylene hydrogenation to low-valued ethane and coke formation were very common. One of the promising routes to selectively remove acetylene from the ethylene-rich feed is the cross-metathesis of acetylene/ethylene to produce 1,3-butadiene worthily. In addition to the selective removal of acetylene, the 1,3-butadiene formed are valuable feedstocks for butadiene-styrene and acrylonitrile−butadiene−styrene copolymers. For acetylene/ethylene cross-metathesis, T. Ioan-Teodor et al. [10] successfully applied the ruthenium carbene complex under the homogeneous system with approximately 70% selectivity of 1,3-butadiene. However, relatively high pressure (11–14 bar) and low temperature (80 °C) are required, and the catalyst can be readily deactivated due to acetylene polymerization. While naphtha steam cracking is operated at low pressure (<2 bar) and high temperature (>700 °C), it is unlikely that such a homogeneous system can be practically applied. Alternatively, heterogeneous catalysts, such as tungsten oxide (WO3), molybdenum oxide (Mo2O3), rhenium oxide (Re2O7), and their mixed oxide have been reported for metathesis. WO3-supported catalyst is the most promising for low-pressure/high-temperature metathesis due to its high stability, low feed sensitivity, and toxicity. It was suggested that the activity of WO3/SiO2 for 2-butene/ethylene metathesis was increased with time and stable after 2 h. This indicated that WO3 was a pre-catalyst for the metathesis from the reduction of WO3 by olefin forming tungsten alkylidene species [11]. However, not all WO3 was uniformly active since the activity was decreased with the formation of bulk WO3, in contrast to monomeric WO3, formed by strong interaction with the supports [12]. Mono- and di-oxo WO3 were found at low metal loading and more active than those polytungstate at a high loading [13]. In a supportive manner, 1-octene metathesis using 8 wt%WO3/SiO2 provides low 7-tetradecene selectivity, as compared to that of 2 wt%WO3/SiO2 [14]. While bulk WO3 preferably promotes isomerization and coke formation. To obtain highly dispersed mono- and di-oxo WO3, low loading WO3 on support with a high surface area, would be considered. The surface OH groups (silanol) adjacent to the active W site assisted in styrene metathesis giving the higher conversion [15]. Moreover, to activate mono-oxo Mo(IV) species with propene, the silanol-assisted pathway is more kinetically accessible than the non-OH-assisted mechanism [16]. The silanol not only assisted in the activation but also affected the structural stabilization of the surface metal oxide species. Therefore, the amount and type of silanol over the surface would be essential to improve the activity. Furthermore, introducing the Lewis acid site (Al3+) can improve the catalytic performance of WO3/Al-MCM- 41 for 1-butene/ethylene cross-metathesis attributing to the maximum monomeric WO3 species and the higher metal-support interaction [17]. However, the cross-metathesis of acetylene/ethylene over supported WO3 catalysts has never been reported. In this work, the selective acetylene/ethylene cross-metathesis using WO3-supported SiO2, MCM-41, SBA-15, NaY, and NaX, were investigated for selective acetylene removal from the ethylene-rich feed. The effect of pretreatment conditions (ethylene and H2 treatment) and WO3 loading on the formation of active WO3 and W=CH2 species were investigated using Raman and in situ Time-Resolved X-ray Absorption Spectroscopy (in situ TR-XAS). The role of the supports with Al-OH and confined structure on the dispersion of WO3 active sites was also studied. The proximity of W=CH2 species was also highlighted. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Ammonium metatungstate tetrahydrate ((NH4)6H2W12O40·4 H2O), triblock copolymer Pluronic P123 (Sigma Aldrich), ethanol (RCI Labscan, 99.9%), hydrochloric acid (Carlo Erba, 37%), sulfuric acid (Carlo Erba, 96%), tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS, Sigma Aldrich, 99%), sodium silicate (Sigma Aldrich, 30–50%), cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB, Sigma Aldrich, 96%), 1-hexene (Carlo Erba, 99%), Davisil SiO2 (Aldrich, 99.9%), Zeolite Y (Carlo Erba, Si/Al 200), and Zeolite X (Carlo Erba, Si/Al 1) were used without further purification. Air-zero (UIG, 99.99%), H2 (UIG, 99.99%), N2 (UIG, 99.999%), C2H4 (UIG, 99.9%) and 1% C2H2 in C2H4 (UIG) were commercially obtained. 2.2 Catalyst preparation SBA-15 was synthesized as described by the literature [18]. Briefly, triblock copolymer Pluronic P123, ethanol, 2 M HCl solution, and deionized water were mixed in the gel composition of 1.0TEOS: 0.017P123: 5.7HCl: 173 H2O: 40 C2H5OH. Subsequently, tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) was added to the solution and stirred continuously at 35 °C for 20 h. Afterward, the gel was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave at 80 °C for 24 h. After washing and drying at 60 °C overnight, the powder was calcined at 550 °C for 6 h with a heating rate of 1 °C·min−1. MCM-41 was also synthesized by the hydrothermal method [19]. 9.90 g of sodium silicate was dissolved in 30 mL of deionized water. The solution was added dropwise with 8.12 g cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) in 80 mL of deionized water and turned into a suspension. The pH of the mixture was adjusted to 10 by dropping 2.0 M H2SO4 solution. The cloudy mixture was vigorously stirred at room temperature for 1 h and then hydrothermally treated at 100 °C for another 48 h. The white precipitate was collected, dried, and calcined at 550 °C for 6 h with a heating rate of 1 °C·min−1. Tungsten oxide precursors (2, 3, 5, and 7 wt% WO3 loading) were incorporated into the supports by the wet impregnation method. Briefly, ammonium metatungstate hydrate was used as a precursor. Typically, the siliceous supports (Davisil SiO2, MCM-41, SBA-15, zeolite NaY, and zeolite NaX) were dried at 110 °C overnight. The tungsten precursor was dissolved in deionized water to make the final concentration of 0.5 M and thoroughly added onto the supports until wet. The impregnated sample was dried at 110 °C for 24 h and calcined at 500 °C for 5 h under air (60 mL·min−1). 2.3 Catalyst characterization XRD of all samples was collected on DMAX2200 Ultima+ (Rigaku) diffractometer using CuKα radiation (λ = 1.504 Å) with 2θ from 0.5˚ to 10˚ and 5˚ to 90˚ at a scanning rate of 5˚/min. XRF analysis was performed on wavelength dispersive X-ray fluorescence spectrophotometer (WD-XRF), S8 Tiger using CuKα radiation (λ = 1.504 Å). N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were recorded by the Autosorb-1 (Quantachrome) instrument. 0.1 g of the samples were evacuated at 300 °C for 12 h under vacuum, and the nitrogen was subjected at − 60 °C for the N2 adsorption-desorption experiment. The samples’ specific surface area and pore size were calculated by the BET method and BJH method, respectively. Raman spectra were collected by Raman spectrometer, Nanoproton, Ramantouch (force) with 785 nm laser, the laser excitation 6.11 mW, and exposure time 100 s from 0 to 2000 cm−1 using Si as standard. DRS-UV spectra were collected on a UV-Vis spectrometer, T92 + , PG instruments. The samples were mixed with BaSO4 and pressed into a sample holder covered by a quartz slide. The data were recorded from 200 to 800 nm using BaSO4 as a baseline reference for all samples. The thermogravimetric analysis curve (TGA) was recorded using a thermogravimetric analyzer, TGA/DSC1, Mettler Toledo. Briefly, ∼10 mg of sample was placed into an Al2O3 crucible and transferred into a thermogravimetric analyzer. The sample was then heated to 900 °C with a heating rate of 5 °C·min−1 under air-zero (30 mL·min−1). The acid properties of the samples were measured by NH3 temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD). The sample 0.2 g was pretreated at 500 °C (heating rate 2·min−1) for 2 h. 1%mol NH3 in He (30 mL·min−1) was purged on the sample for 1 h and then flushed by He at 30 °C for 1 h to remove excess NH3. The NH3-TPD profile was detected from 30° to 900°C with a heating rate of 10 °C·min−1 using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The NH3 signal was calibrated by a pulse of 1%mol NH3 in He, using a 100 µL sample loop. The reducibility of the samples was measured by H2 temperature-programmed reduction. The sample was activated in a similar procedure. The reduction profile was measured under 10%H2/Ar from 50° to 900°C with a heating rate of 10 °C·min−1 using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The signal was calibrated by a pulse of 1%mol H2/Ar in a 100 µL sample loop and CuO standard. In situ Time-resolved X-ray absorption spectroscopy (in situ TR-XAS) was conducted at beamline 2.2 XAS of the Synchrotron Light Research Institute (SLRI), Thailand. W L3-edge in situ TR-XANES and EXAFS spectra were measured in transmission mode using a Si (111) bent-crystal monochromator and a linear image NMOS sensor. The data were collected simultaneously during the experiment. The sample was initially heated under air (30 mL·min−1) from room temperature to 500 °C with a heating rate of 2 °C·min−1 and held for 3 h. Subsequently, the sample was heated to 600 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C·min−1 under He (30 mL·min−1). When the sample reached 600 °C, the saturated vapor of 1-hexene in He (45 °C) was introduced (30 mL·min−1) with a weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 45 h−1. The spectra were normalized, processed, and analyzed on Athena software. The coordination and structural information were simulated on Artemis software using W2O7 and WO3 as model structures. 2.4 Catalytic testing The catalysts were pressed and sieved at 600–850 µm. They were packed into a quartz tube of 8 mm diameter. Quartz beads were filled at the upper layer, while the bottom was filled with quartz rods. Before the activity testing, the catalyst was pretreated under 30 mL·min−1 of air at 500 °C for 4 h; afterward, N2 was subjected until 600 °C and activated under 30 mL·min−1of ethylene for 2 h. Then, the temperature was held at 450 °C and the reaction started by switching from ethylene (30 mL·min−1) to 1% acetylene in ethylene (15 mL·min−1). The gas products were periodically collected every 20 min for 6 h using online GC, Agilent 6890 equipped with Al2O3 plot column; 250 µL sample loop, injector 250 °C, isothermal 100 °C for 30 min, detector 300 °C. Acetylene removal, yield, selectivity, and turnover frequency were calculated by the following equations: Acetylene removal ( % ) = weight of acetylene 0 − weight of acetylene t weight of acetylene 0 × 100 Yield ( % ) = weight of product A t weight of acetylene 0 × 100 Selectivity ( % ) = Yield of product A ( % ) Acetylene removal ( % ) × 100 TOF ( h − 1 ) = mol of converted acetylene mol of WO 3 × time ( h ) W / F ( g . h . mol − 1 ) = catalyst weight ( g ) mol of acetylene / time ( h ) 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Physicochemical properties of WO3/SiO2 catalysts The surface area and chemical composition of the supported tungsten oxide over silica are summarized in Table 1. The WO3 loading in each catalyst is close to the expected values. All loaded WO3 samples showed a lower surface area (365–248 m2/g) than its parent support (385 m2/g). The higher the WO3 loading, the lower the surface area. This could be attributed to the loaded WO3 could cover the surface of the SiO2. The crystallite WO3 diffraction peaks were only observed in 7%WO3/SiO2, as shown in Fig. 1A (d), suggesting that bulk WO3 was present in 7%WO3/SiO2. In a supportive manner, UV–VIS DRS spectra of the 7%WO3/SiO2 showed an absorption at 457 nm (Fig. 1B (d)), representing the bulk WO3 species as reported by Ross-Medgaarden et al. [20] . The band gap energy of these samples (∼2.75 eV, Table S1) is also consistent with the bulk WO3 (2.80 eV). In contrast, the lower absorption (230 and 350 nm, Fig. 1B (a-c)) was observed for 2–5%WO3/SiO2, with higher band gap energy (4.5 and 5.2 eV, Table S1) that corresponds to the isolated WO3 (i.e., di-oxo and mono-oxo WO3) or smaller WO3 clusters (i.e., dimeric WO3 and WO3 clusters) [13]. In line with this view, only Raman spectra of 7%WO3/SiO2 (Fig. 1C (d)) showed the WO vibrations of bulk WO3 at 268 cm-1 (δ(WO), 711 (ν as(WO)), and 804 cm-1 (ν s(WO)) [20]. Furthermore, W 5d ligand field splitting of an octahedral W unit could be observed in the 2nd derivative in situ TR-XANES spectra of 7%WO3/SiO2 (Figure S1). The W L3-edge in situ TR-EXAFS spectra of 7%WO3/SiO2 (Fig. 1D) also show the radial distance at 1.37 and 2.75 Å for W-O and W-O-W bond, corresponding to the bulk WO3 species as reported by Kuzmin and Purans [21]. On the other hand, bulk WO3 characteristic peak was not detected in the Raman spectra of 2%WO3/SiO2, 3%WO3/SiO2, and 5%WO3/SiO2 (Fig. 1 C (a-c)). W L3-edge in situ TR-XANES and the 2nd derivative spectra of 5%WO3/SiO2 also showed a similar single asymmetrical peak of tetrahedral tungsten oxide in contrast to a doublet peak of octahedral W unit in 7%WO3/SiO2 and (NH3)6H2W12O40 (Figure S1). Moreover, Fourier transforms of W L3-edge in situ TR-EXAFS spectra of this sample show only 1st shell W-O coordination (Fig. 1D). The Raman shifts at ∼998, and 1025 cm-1 for mono-oxo WO3 species with four and five coordination (OW(O-Si)3 and OW(O-Si)4) were particularly pronounced in 2%WO3/SiO2 ( Fig. 2a). In addition, weak scattering peaks at 975 and 985 cm-1 reveal the formation of WO3 clusters and di-oxo WO3 ((O=)2W(O-Si)2) [22–24], as shown in Fig. 2. At the same time, the WO3 cluster (975 cm-1) was predominant in 3%WO3/SiO2 and 5%WO3/SiO2 samples. The difference in WO3 species, as evidenced by Raman spectroscopy, suggests that the formation of WO3 depends on WO3 loading compared to the available silanol on the surface of the supports. At a low WO3 loading (2%WO3/SiO2), WO3 tends to disperse in a monomeric form (di-oxo and mono-oxo WO3). This is because the surface silanol is sufficiently available for anchoring WO3 species. With a relatively strong interaction between the surface silanol and the tungsten precursors (i.e., (NH3)6H2W12O40) [25], agglomeration to bulk WO3 is somewhat inhibited upon calcination. As the WO3 loading increases, the tungsten precursor remains in close proximity, weakening the interaction between the surface silanol and the WO3. Accordingly, agglomeration to bulk WO3 was observed, particularly for the 7%WO3/SiO2. Consequently, surface silanol of the support plays a significant role in accommodating monomeric WO3, which would be the most active species for the acetylene/ethylene cross-metathesis [16]. 3.2 Acetylene/ethylene cross-metathesis over WO3/SiO2 catalysts Over the as-prepared 5%WO3/SiO2, acetylene removal is gradually increased with time on stream, as seen in Fig. 3A (a). This suggests that the as-prepared WO3 was not an active site but a catalyst precursor for acetylene/ethylene cross-metathesis. The hydrocarbon feed (ethylene or acetylene) would primarily react with the WO3 during the reaction to form W4+ alkylidene species (W=CH2) via pseudo-Wittig reaction ( Scheme 1), as suggested in the literature [26]. The acetylene/ethylene metathesis over this W4+ alkylidene active site initially is proceeded by [2 + 2] cycloaddition of M=CH2 (i) and acetylene, forming a 4-membered metallocyclic intermediate (ii). Then, the ring-opening of intermediate (ii) would yield vinyl carbene tungsten intermediate (iii) that could undergo [2 + 2] cycloaddition with ethylene, forming a four-membered metallocyclic intermediate (iv). The rearrangement of the intermediate (iv) would result in 1,3-butadiene, recovering active W=CH2 species (i) as shown in Scheme 1. The acetylene removal rapidly increased after in situ treatment with ethylene at 450 °C for 2 h. Similarly, the ethylene treatment at 600 °C can readily improve the induction period, and a steady-state removal can be reached within 2 h. This indicates that ethylene treatment can primarily promote the formation of W=CH2 species and consequently suppress the induction period [13]. Supportively, higher acetylene removal was obtained over the catalyst with ethylene-treating at 600 °C compared to the prepared WO3/SiO2 (Fig. 3B). At a similar conversion, the ethylene-treated WO3/SiO2 requires ∼25 °C lower than the as-prepared WO3/SiO2. According to the temperature profile, the reaction temperature of 450 °C was applied for selective acetylene removal throughout this work. As an active W=CH2 must be generated from WO species, a concentration of surface WO would determine the catalytic activity. Accordingly, the 5%WO3/SiO2 reduced at 500 °C for 2 h before treatment with ethylene at 600 °C provides a lower acetylene removal (37%) compared to the non-reduced catalyst (44%, Fig. 4). The reduced 5%WO3/SiO2 without ethylene treatment even showed lower activity than those without reduced. This can be explained by a reduction of surface WO as seen from the hydrogen consumption at ∼450 °C in the H2-TPR profile ( Fig. 5A). In line with this view, the average oxidation state of WO3 species in 5%WO3/SiO2 decreased from + 6.0 to + 5.3 (Table S2, entries 1–2) after reduction at 500 °C. These values were estimated from W L3-edge energy using WO3 (W6+), (NH4)6H2W12O40 (W6+), and W foil (W0) standards, as shown in Figure S2. Jiang et al. [27] have also mentioned that, upon H2 reduction, the oxo group at the oxygen-terminated surface was readily removed as water, leading to a lower concentration of surface WO (the active site precursor) with a decrease in average W oxidation state (a combination of W6+ and W4+ species), as proposed in Scheme 2. In a supportive manner, W L3-edge in situ Time-Resolved EXAFS spectra (in situ TR-EXAFS) for the reduced 5%WO3/SiO2 at 500 °C also evidenced a decrease in W-O first shell intensity, as shown in Fig. 5B. This again suggested that the reduction of WO3 leads to lower oxygen coordination around tungsten (from 4.0 to 3.7, Table 2, entry 2, Figure S3). In line with this view, Wilken et al. report that a few amounts of WO3 can be partially reduced to form WO2.90 [28]. A decrease in surface WO concentration would result in a decreased activity but not selectivity. This is because the remaining WO can be transformed to active W=CH2 sites, promoting acetylene removal via acetylene/ethylene cross-metathesis with a similar 1,3-butadiene selectivity for both reduced and non-reduced catalysts. As the surface WO is required to form active W=CH2, the acetylene removal was linearly enhanced with WO3 loading, as shown in Fig. 6A. 1,3-butadiene was also increasingly produced as a major product (78–85% selectivity). At the same time, cyclohexene was a secondary product emerging from Diels-Alder of ethylene and the 1,3-butadiene primarily produced ( Scheme 3) [29,30]. It is likely that, in excess of ethylene, the 1,3-butadiene formed on the surface may well react with ethylene before desorption. For the same reason, high ethylene coverage results in the dimerization of 1-butene and 2-butene, as detected in trace amounts [31,32]. The acetylene removal was also raised with W/F, as presented in Fig. 6B. 1,3-butadiene yield was increased to a greater extent, up to ∼68%, while cyclohexene was steadily produced to ∼12% yield. The reaction pathway for acetylene removal via ethylene/acetylene cross-metathesis over 5%WO3/SiO2 is present in Scheme 3. Despite a linear relation between activity and WO3 loading, the turn-over-frequency (TOF) was decreased with WO3 loading, as shown in Table 3. This suggests that relatively less active W species are present at the high WO3 loading. As 7%WO3/SiO2 contained mainly bulk WO3 (as discussed earlier in Fig. 1), the decrease in TOF at high WO3 loadings could be attributed to the presence of this species that has been previously observed by Wang et al. [33]. This is because the bulk WO3 crystallites possess a relatively less external surface, leading to low WO species - an active site precursor for acetylene/ethylene cross-metathesis. The lower WO species were also reported for bulk WO3 compared to highly dispersed WO3 on the silica support [34–37]. Feed flow rate 20 mL·min-1 (acetylene/ethylene = 1/99 wt%), N2 flow rate 35 mL·min-1, 450 °C, activation in ethylene at 600 °C for 2 h. a Evaluated at 300 min on stream. On the other hand, the catalyst with low WO3 loading, particularly 2%WO3/SiO2, provides TOF up to 53 h-1. No bulk WO3 was observed in this catalyst, while the monomeric WO3, e.g., mono and di-oxo WO3, were mainly present, as shown in Fig. 2. This suggests that such single-site WO3 is more active than the bulk species, presumably due to a higher dispersion. While the 3%WO3/SiO2 and 5%WO3/SiO2 exhibit TOF lower than 2%WO3/SiO2. This is because these catalysts contain mainly WO3 clusters with a relatively small amount of monomeric WO3, as discussed earlier (Fig. 2). Despite high dispersion, the monomeric WO3 species (found primarily on 2%WO3/SiO2) appears to be more active than the WO3 clusters (mainly found in 3% and 5%WO3/SiO2). This is because the monomeric WO3 possessed relatively high electron density around the fermi level attributed to O-2p electrons and W-5d electrons [38–41]. In line with this view, a lower average W oxidation state of + 5.6 was observed in 2%WO3/SiO2 when compared to 6.0 of the WO3 cluster in 5%WO3/SiO2 (Table S2, entries 1 and 3). Such high electron density may facilitate the formation of W=CH2 species that promotes overall [2 + 2] cycloaddition for the acetylene/ethylene cross-metathesis. In sharp contrast, the lower electron density of WO3 species in 5%WO3/SiO2 and 7%WO3/SiO2 (average W oxidation state of +6.0 and +6.3, Table S2, entries 1 and 4) would destabilize the W=CH2 species, resulting in a decreased reaction rate. In a similar manner, [4 + 2] cycloaddition (Diels-Alder) activity would also decrease, leading to low cyclohexene selectivity (∼18% selectivity) over 7%WO3/SiO2, as compared to those over the 2%− 5%WO3/SiO2 (23–25% selectivity). 3.3 Effect of supports on WO3 /W=CH2 species In addition to the WO3 loading, the formation of active single-site WO3 depends on the interaction between WO3 and the silica support. As the surface silanol acts as an anchoring site for WO3, a higher number of silanol could readily accommodate the single-site WO3, the most active species, as discussed previously. For this reason, increasing WO3-support interaction and anchoring sites would favor the supports with surface Al-OH. Accordingly, 5%WO3/NaY and 5%WO3/NaX were examined to compare with 5%WO3/SiO2 (in which only the WO3 cluster is formed). It can be seen from Fig. 7A(a) that bulk WO3 was the only species formed over 5%WO3/NaY, while the WO3 cluster was formed over 5%WO3/NaX (Fig. 7A (b)). Despite similar surface area for both supports ( Table 4, entries 1 and 2), a higher Al-OH density in 5%WO3/NaX probably provides proper site proximity, accommodating smaller WO3 species as seen by DR-UV (Figure S4A). This indicates that Al-OH over NaY and NaX could play a role in anchoring WO3. The strong interaction between WO3 and Al-OH was also observed in H2-TPR, as shown in Figure S4B. However, 5%WO3/NaY provides a lower acetylene removal and TOF (25 h-1, Table 5, entry 1) compared to 5%WO3/SiO2 (35 h-1, Table 3, entry 3). As mentioned earlier, this is presumably because of the less active WO3 (bulk) formation. Moreover, an exposed Al-OH in this support would result in higher-strength acid sites (Table 4, entry 1–2, Figure S5). This can readily promote acetylene/ethylene oligomerization and coke formation, which rapidly deactivates the catalyst, as evidenced by the TGA result (Figure S6). Maksasithorn et al. reported that the NaOH-treated acid site mitigation of WO3/SiO2 can suppress coke formation [42]. In a supportive manner, 5%WO3/NaX, Al-OH rich support, shows no activity for acetylene/ethylene cross-metathesis (Table 4 entry 2), despite a more active WO3 cluster being present in this catalyst. Feed flow rate 20 mL·min-1 (acetylene/ethylene = 1/99 mol/mol), N2 flow rate 35 mL·min-1, 450 °C, activation in ethylene at 600 °C for 2 h. a Evaluated at 300 min In sharp contrast, low-acidic supports (none of Al-OH) with higher surface area and hexagonal pore structure, namely 5%WO3/MCM-41 and 5%WO3/SBA-15, provides higher acetylene removal (58% and 62%, Table 5 entry 3–4) and stability (Figure S7). 1,3-butadiene selectivity was also slightly enhanced (85%), and very low selectivity of cyclohexene was observed (14%) (Table 5, entry 3). This is because these supports possess a relatively high surface area (Table 4, entries 4–5) compared to the typical silica support. Moreover, the isolated silanol within the confined hexagonal mesoporous SiO2 would be favorable for anchoring WO3 species, presumably due to an increase in the three-dimensional local hydrogen bond density [43]. Accordingly, various types of monomeric WO3 species (Fig. 2) would be dispersed in 5%WO3/MCM-41 and 5%WO3/SBA-15, leading to a high amount of exposed W=CH2 active site on the surface for acetylene/ethylene cross-metathesis. The formation of such highly dispersed WO3 in 5%WO3/MCM-41% and 5%WO3/SBA-15 was evidenced by the peak of mono-oxo WO3 species with four coordination (OW(O-Si)3) at 998 cm-1 in Raman spectra (Fig. 7B I and (d)) [44–46], similar to that found in 2%WO3/SiO2 (Fig. 2). Gao et al. suggested that the OW(O-Si)3 with a strongly bound W-O-Si covalent bond can be observed over meso-cellular silica foam [34]. Yang et al. also reported that OW(O-Si)3 can be formed over SBA-15 [37]. In addition, in situ TR-XANES of 5%WO3/MCM-41% and 5%WO3/SBA-15 shows the W L3-edge energy of 10208.9 eV and average W oxidation state of + 5.3 (Table S2, entries 7 and 8), consistent to W5+ in the OW(O-Si)3. In a supportive manner, in situ TR-EXAFS fitting exhibits the WO3 species with a coordination number (CN) of 4 for both 5%WO3/MCM-41% and 5%WO3/SBA-15 (Table 2, entries 3 and 4, Figure S9). The lower W L3-edge energy and average W oxidation state (+5.3) were observed for 5%WO3/MCM-41% and 5%WO3/SBA-15, as compared to 2%WO3/SiO2. This is because the additional W6+ species, i.e., OW6+(O-Si)4 and (O=)2W6+(O-Si)2, were present in 2%WO3/SiO2, providing the average W oxidation state of + 5.6. Accordingly, the mono-oxo WO3 species with four coordination (OW(O-Si)3) would mainly exist in these confined silica supports. In a supportive manner, the OW6+(O-Si)4 and (O=)2W6+(O-Si)2 species were not detected by the Raman spectra. (Figs. 2 and 7B). When 5%WO3/MCM-41 and 5%WO3/SBA-15 were treated with 1-hexene at 600 °C, the formation of W=CH2 active sites from the OW(O-Si)3 species during the olefin treatment can be evidenced by a sudden redshift (within 5 min) in the W edge energy (∼0.4 eV, Table 6). This suggests the rapid reduction of WO species to W=CH2 species by “pseudo-Wittig” reaction with 1-hexene, as discussed previously in Section 3.2. This is because these catalysts possess high surface silanols that promote the formation of W=CH2 species. Handzlik et al. also reported that the silanol group adjacent to WO3 could assist in the activation of the mono-oxo Mo(IV) species to form W=CH2 species in which it is more kinetically accessible than those non-OH-assisted mechanisms [16]. Accordingly, the catalysts with OW(O-Si)3 species would provide a higher amount of the exposed W=CH2 active site on the surface. While, for the WO3 clusters in 5%WO3/SiO2, there might be some unreactive tungsten species that remained on the surface after contacting with 1-hexene. This could be supported by a slightly higher average W oxidation state of + 4.3 for 5%WO3/SiO2, compared to that of + 4.1 for 5%WO3/SBA-15 and 5%WO3/MCM-41. It is worth noting that the tetrahedral structure of these W species was retained during 1-hexene treatment at 600 °C for 1 h, as deduced from a similar 2nd derivative W L3-edge TR-XANES spectra (Figure S10). Although the electronic state and local structure of the active W=CH2 was somewhat similar for 5%WO3/MCM-41% and 5%WO3/SBA-15, as compared to 5%WO3/SiO2, Fourier transforms W L3-edge in situ TR-EXAFS spectra suggest the formation of only isolated W=CH2 site for 5%WO3/MCM-41% and 5%WO3/SBA-15, as shown in Figs. 8A and 8B. Despite a similar first shell radial distance for W-O and W-C coordination [22], no higher coordination shell (3–4 and 6–8 Å) can be observed over 5%WO3/MCM-41 and 5%WO3/SBA-15. This implies the formation of single-site W=CH2 species (CH2 =W(O-Si)3) after treating with 1-hexene at 600 °C. In addition, the relative intensity of first shell W-C (or W-O) scattering ( Fig. 9A) remains constant during the treatment for 1 h, indicating a high stability of such single-site W=CH2 species in 5%WO3/MCM-41 and 5%WO3/SBA-15. This isolated and stable W=CH2 single site could promote a rapid [2 + 2] cycloaddition and higher acetylene removal and be responsible for the observed high activity of these catalysts. In a different manner, a higher coordination W-C shell (3–4 and 6–8 Å) can be observed in 5%WO3/SiO2 (Fig. 8C). This again suggests that the W=CH2 species generated from the WO3 cluster (in 5%WO3/SiO2) exist in close proximity, compared to that generated from mono-oxo WO3 (in 5%WO3/MCM-41 and 5%WO3/SBA-15). This probably promotes the oligomerization of higher olefins, as reported by Spamer et al. [47]. In fact, the TGA result under air-zero of 5%WO3/SiO2 after ethylene treatment shows a higher carbon content than 5%WO3/MCM-41 and 5%WO3/SBA-15 (Figure S11). In line with this view, the relative intensity of second shell scattering (presumably W-C) keeps increasing after treatment with 1-hexene (Fig. 9B). The formation of coke deposits in close proximity to the W=CH2 active site would limit accessibility and hence activity of 5%WO3/SiO2, as compared to 5%WO3/MCM-41 and 5%WO3/SBA-15. One could expect that the pore size may affect the catalytic performance other than the WO3 species present in the catalysts. This is not the case for this study since the rate of metathesis is considerably fast, and the reaction is thermodynamically controlled. Moreover, the acetylene/ethylene metathesis is not shape-selective. Kinetic diameters of both reactants and products are relatively small (<0.4 nm) as compared to the pore size of SBA-15 and MCM-41 (3–50 nm). There would be no external and/or internal diffusion limitation for this reaction. Accordingly, the pore size of SBA-15 and MCM-41 investigated shall not affect the observed intrinsic rate. 4 Conclusion Acetylene removal from ethylene-rich feed can be achieved by acetylene/ethylene cross-metathesis using WO3-supported catalysts. Ethylene treatment can activate WO3 to W=CH2, an active site for the acetylene/ethylene cross-metathesis. 1,3-butadiene was produced as a major product (78% selectivity) together with minor product cyclohexene (14% selectivity) from the Diels-Alder reaction between 1,3-butadiene and ethylene. The hydrogen treatment of WO3 leads to a decrease in WO and WO3 agglomeration, resulting in a declined acetylene removal activity. The mono-oxo and di-oxo WO3 species formed in 2%WO3/SiO2 provide a higher rate of acetylene removal (53 h-1) compared to the WO3 cluster (45 h-1, for 3–5%WO3/SiO2) and bulk WO3 (30 h-1, for 7%WO3/SiO2). Though the framework Al acts as an anchoring site for higher WO3 dispersion, 5%WO3/NaX and 5%WO3/NaY give lower acetylene removal due to coke formation from the acid sites during ethylene treatment. For the confined siliceous supports, the mono-oxo WO3 species with four coordination (CH2 =W(O-Si)3) in 5%WO3/MCM-41 and 5%WO3/SBA-15 provides relatively higher activity (40 and 46 h-1) compared to the WO3 cluster in 5%WO3/SiO2. Although a similar electronic property of W=CH2 species (average W oxidation state of +4.2) formed from both the mono-oxo WO3 and WO3 cluster, an isolated and stable W=CH2 species generated from the mono-oxo WO3 readily promotes [2 + 2] cycloaddition for acetylene/ethylene cross-metathesis. In addition, the coke formation is less pronounced over the isolated W=CH2 species than that generated from the WO3 cluster. The findings could lend an alternative approach for ethylene purification simply by adding a supported WO3 catalytic bed at the cracker exit. coredata.dc:description: Acetylene in ethylene-rich feed can be removed via acetylene/ethylene cross-metathesis over WO3-supported catalysts at 450 °C, yielding 1,3-butadiene with cyclohexene as a minor product. The catalyst must be treated with ethylene at 600 °C to generate a genuinely active site of tungsten (IV) alkylidene species (W=CH2). The H2 treatment decreases surface WO concentration, and hence the activity. Raman spectroscopy shows that active single-site WO3 species, including mono oxo-WO3 ((O=)W(O-Si)3 and (O=)W(O-Si)4) and dioxo-WO3 species (O=)2W(O-Si)2) were generated in 2%WO3/SiO2, while the WO3 cluster and bulk WO3 exist in 3–5%WO3/SiO2 and 7%WO3/SiO2, respectively. The 5%WO3/NaX and 5%WO3/NaY provide lower activity due to coke formation over the acid sites. With high surface area and confined surface silanol of 5%WO3/MCM-41% and 5%WO3/SBA-15, in situ TR-EXAFS evidences the formation of only OW(O-Si)3. This species provides an isolated W=CH2 site with relatively higher activity and is less prone to coke formation than the WO3 cluster in 5%WO3/SiO2.
coredata.dc:title: Selective acetylene removal from ethylene-rich feed by cross-metathesis over supported WO3 catalysts
